License: arXiv.org perpetual non-exclusive license
arXiv:2410.04887v1 [cs.LG] 07 Oct 2024

Wide Neural Networks Trained with Weight Decay
Provably Exhibit Neural Collapse

Arthur Jacot,    Peter Súkeník,    Zihan Wang,    and Marco Mondelli Courant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU. Email: arthur.jacot@nyu.eduInstitute of Science and Technology Austria. Email: peter.sukenik@ista.ac.atCourant Institute of Mathematical Sciences, NYU. Email: zw3508@nyu.eduInstitute of Science and Technology Austria. Email: marco.mondelli@ist.ac.at
Abstract

Deep neural networks (DNNs) at convergence consistently represent the training data in the last layer via a highly symmetric geometric structure referred to as neural collapse. This empirical evidence has spurred a line of theoretical research aimed at proving the emergence of neural collapse, mostly focusing on the unconstrained features model. Here, the features of the penultimate layer are free variables, which makes the model data-agnostic and, hence, puts into question its ability to capture DNN training. Our work addresses the issue, moving away from unconstrained features and studying DNNs that end with at least two linear layers. We first prove generic guarantees on neural collapse that assume (i) low training error and balancedness of the linear layers (for within-class variability collapse), and (ii) bounded conditioning of the features before the linear part (for orthogonality of class-means, as well as their alignment with weight matrices). We then show that such assumptions hold for gradient descent training with weight decay: (i) for networks with a wide first layer, we prove low training error and balancedness, and (ii) for solutions that are either nearly optimal or stable under large learning rates, we additionally prove the bounded conditioning. Taken together, our results are the first to show neural collapse in the end-to-end training of DNNs.

1 Introduction

Among the many possible interpolators that a deep neural network (DNN) can find, Papyan et al. (2020) showed a strong bias of gradient-based training towards representations with a highly symmetric structure in the penultimate layer, which was dubbed neural collapse (NC). In particular, the feature vectors of the training data in the penultimate layer collapse to a single vector per class (NC1); these vectors form orthogonal or simplex equiangular tight frames (NC2), and they are aligned with the last layer’s row weight vectors (NC3). The question of why and how neural collapse emerges has been considered by a popular line of research, see e.g. Lu & Steinerberger (2022); E & Wojtowytsch (2022) and the discussion in Section 2. Many of these works focus on a simplified mathematical framework: the unconstrained features model (UFM) (Mixon et al., 2020; Han et al., 2022; Zhou et al., 2022a), corresponding to the joint optimization over the last layer’s weights and the penultimate layer’s feature representations, which are treated as free variables. To account for the existence of the training data and of all the layers before the penultimate (i.e., the backbone of the network), some form of regularization on the free features is usually added. A number of papers has proved the optimality of NC in this model (Lu & Steinerberger, 2022; E & Wojtowytsch, 2022), its emergence with gradient-based methods (Mixon et al., 2020; Han et al., 2022) and a benign loss landscape (Zhou et al., 2022a; Zhu et al., 2021). However, the major drawback of the UFM lies in its data-agnostic nature: it only acknowledges the presence of training data and backbone through a simple form of regularization (e.g., Frobenius norm or sphere constraint), which is far from being equivalent to end-to-end training. Moving beyond UFM, existing results are either only applicable to rather shallow networks (of at most three layers) (Kothapalli & Tirer, 2024; Hong & Ling, 2024) or hold under strong assumptions, such as symmetric quasi-interpolation (Xu et al., 2023; Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey, 2022), block-structured empirical NTK throughout training (Seleznova et al., 2023), or geodesic structure of the features across all layers (Wang et al., 2024).

In this paper, we provide the first end-to-end proof of within-class variability collapse (NC1) for a class of networks that end with at least two linear layers. Furthermore, we give rather weak sufficient conditions – either near-optimality or stability under large learning rates – for solutions to exhibit the orthogonality of class-means (NC2) and the alignment of class means with the last weight matrix (NC3). More precisely, our contributions can be summarized as follows:

  • •

    First, we show that within-class variability collapse (i.e., NC1) occurs, as long as the training error is low and the linear layers are approximately balanced, i.e., ‖Wℓ+1T⁢Wℓ+1−Wℓ⁢WℓT‖Fsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ1𝑇subscript𝑊ℓ1subscript𝑊ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ𝑇𝐹\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{T}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{T}\right\|_{F}∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small, where Wℓ+1,Wℓsubscript𝑊ℓ1subscript𝑊ℓW_{\ell+1},W_{\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are two consecutive weight matrices of the linear head. If, additionally, the conditioning of the linear head mapping is bounded, we bound the conditioning of the matrix of class means in the last layer, as well as that of the last weight matrix. This implies that, as the number of linear layers grows, class means become orthogonal and, furthermore, they align with the last layer’s row vectors, which proves both NC2 and NC3.

  • •

    Next, we show that the sufficient conditions above for NC1 are satisfied by a class of deep networks with a wide first layer, smooth activations and pyramidal topology, after gradient training with weight decay. This provides the first guarantee of the emergence of NC1 for a deep network trained end-to-end via gradient descent.

  • •

    We further present two sufficient conditions under which the linear head is guaranteed to be well-conditioned, hence NC1, NC2 and NC3 hold: either the network approaches a global optimum of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized square loss, or it nearly interpolates the data while being stable under large learning rates.

  • •

    Our numerical experiments on various architectures (fully connected, ResNet) and datasets (MNIST, CIFAR) confirm the insights coming from the theory: (i) NC2 is more prominent as the depth of the linear head increases, and (ii) the final linear layers are balanced at convergence. Furthermore, we show that, as the non-linear part of the network gets deeper, the non-negative layers become less non-linear and more balanced.

2 Related Work

Neural collapse.

Since its introduction by Papyan et al. (2020), neural collapse has been intensively studied, both from a theoretical and practical viewpoint. Practitioners use the NC for a number of applications, including transfer learning, OOD detection and generalization bounds (Galanti et al., 2022a; Haas et al., 2022; Ben-Shaul & Dekel, 2022; Li et al., 2023a, b; Zhang et al., 2024). On the theoretical front, the most widely adopted framework to study the emergence of NC is the unconstrained features model (UFM) (Mixon et al., 2020; Fang et al., 2021). Under the UFM, the NC has been proved to be optimal with cross-entropy loss (E & Wojtowytsch, 2022; Lu & Steinerberger, 2022; Kunin et al., 2022), MSE loss (Zhou et al., 2022a) and other losses (Zhou et al., 2022b). Optimality guarantees for the generalization of NC to the class-imbalanced setting have been provided by Fang et al. (2021); Thrampoulidis et al. (2022); Hong & Ling (2023); Dang et al. (2024). Besides global optimality, a benign loss landscape around NC solutions has been proved in Zhu et al. (2021); Ji et al. (2022); Zhou et al. (2022a), and the emergence of NC with gradient-based optimization under UFM has been studied by Mixon et al. (2020); Han et al. (2022); Ji et al. (2022); Wang et al. (2022). Jiang et al. (2023) extend the analysis to large number of classes, Kothapalli et al. (2023) to graph neural networks, Tirer et al. (2023) generalize UFM with a perturbation to account for its imperfections, while Andriopoulos et al. (2024) generalize UFM and NC to regression problems. A deep neural collapse is theoretically analyzed with deep UFM for the linear case in Dang et al. (2023); Garrod & Keating (2024), for the non-linear case with two layers in Tirer & Bruna (2022), and for the deep non-linear case in Súkeník et al. (2023, 2024), where, notably, the latter work provides the first negative result on deep NC with deep UFM.

A line of recent work aims at circumventing the data-agnostic nature of UFM, showing the emergence of neural collapse in settings closer to practice. Specifically, Seleznova et al. (2023) assume a block structure in the empirical NTK matrix. Kernels are used by Kothapalli & Tirer (2024) to analyze NC in wide two-layer networks, showing mostly negative results in the NTK regime. Beaglehole et al. (2024) prove the emergence of deep neural collapse using kernel-based layer-wise training, and they show that NC is an optimal solution of adaptive kernel ridge regression in an over-parametrized regime. Sufficient (but rather strong) conditions for the emergence of NC beyond UFM are provided by Pan & Cao (2023). Hong & Ling (2024) analyze two and three layer networks end-to-end, but only provide conditions under which the UFM optimal solutions are feasible. Wang et al. (2024) consider the NC formation in residual networks, and the model is similar to the perturbed UFM in Tirer et al. (2023). However, the results crucially assume that the features lie on a geodesic in euclidean space, and proving that this is the case after training the ResNet is an open problem. Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey (2022); Xu et al. (2023) focus on homogeneous networks trained via gradient-based methods, making the strong assumption of symmetric quasi-interpolation. Then, Rangamani & Banburski-Fahey (2022) do not prove this assumption, and the argument of Xu et al. (2023) requires a regularization different from the one used in practice as well as interpolators with a given norm (whose existence is an open question). We also note that the quasi-interpolation property does not hold in practice exactly, which points to the need of a perturbation analysis.

Implicit bias.

Our approach leverages the (approximate) balancedness of the weights, which plays a central role in the analysis of the training dynamics of linear networks (Arora et al., 2018b) and leads to a bias towards low-rank matrices (Arora et al., 2019; Tu et al., 2024). In the presence of weight decay, the low-rank bias can be made even more explicit (Dai et al., 2021), and it is reinforced by stochastic gradient descent (Wang & Jacot, 2024). Moving towards nonlinear models, shallow networks with weight decay exhibit low-rank bias, as described by the variational norm (Bach, 2017), or Barron norm (E et al., 2019), and this bias provably emerges under (modified) GD dynamics (Abbe et al., 2022; Bietti et al., 2022; Lee et al., 2024). However, a single hidden layer appears to be insufficient to exhibit NC for most datasets. Moving towards deep nonlinear models, networks with weight decay are also known to exhibit low-rank bias (Galanti et al., 2022b; Jacot et al., 2022), which can be related to neural collapse (Zangrando et al., 2024). The dimensionality and rank of the weights/representations varies between layers, exhibiting a bottleneck structure (Jacot, 2023a, b; Wen & Jacot, 2024). We remark that existing results apply to the global minima of the ℓ2subscriptℓ2\ell_{2}roman_ℓ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-regularized loss. In contrast, our paper provides rather general sufficient conditions that are then provably satisfied by GD, thus showing that the training algorithm is responsible for neural collapse.

3 Balancedness and Interpolation Imply Neural Collapse

Notation and problem setup.

We denote by ‖A‖F,‖A‖o⁢psubscriptnorm𝐴𝐹subscriptnorm𝐴𝑜𝑝\|A\|_{F},\|A\|_{op}∥ italic_A ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ italic_A ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and σmin⁢(A)subscript𝜎min𝐴\sigma_{\textrm{min}}\left(A\right)italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_A ) its Frobenius norm, its operator norm and its smallest singular value, respectively.

where the activation function σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ is applied componentwise and, given an integer n𝑛nitalic_n, we use the shorthand [n]:={1,…,n}assigndelimited-[]𝑛1…𝑛[n]:=\{1,\ldots,n\}[ italic_n ] := { 1 , … , italic_n }. We index individual samples in a feature matrix Z𝑍Zitalic_Z as zc⁢i,subscript𝑧𝑐𝑖z_{ci},italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , meaning the i𝑖iitalic_i-th sample of the c𝑐citalic_c-th class, sometimes adding an upper-index to denote the layer or matrix to which the sample belongs. Let μcsubscript𝜇𝑐\mu_{c}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the mean of all samples from class c𝑐citalic_c and μGsubscript𝜇𝐺\mu_{G}italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the global mean. Let Z¯¯𝑍\bar{Z}over¯ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG be the matrix of class-means stacked into columns. The NC1 metric on a feature matrix Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is given by tr⁢(ΣW)tr⁢(ΣB),trsubscriptΣ𝑊trsubscriptΣ𝐵\frac{\text{tr}(\Sigma_{W})}{\text{tr}(\Sigma_{B})},divide start_ARG tr ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG tr ( roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG , where ΣW=1N⁢∑c,i(zc⁢i−μc)⁢(zc⁢i−μc)⊤subscriptΣ𝑊1𝑁subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑧𝑐𝑖subscript𝜇𝑐superscriptsubscript𝑧𝑐𝑖subscript𝜇𝑐top\Sigma_{W}=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}(z_{ci}-\mu_{c})(z_{ci}-\mu_{c})^{\top}roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and ΣB=1K⁢∑c=1K(μc−μG)⁢(μc−μG)⊤.subscriptΣ𝐵1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑐1𝐾subscript𝜇𝑐subscript𝜇𝐺superscriptsubscript𝜇𝑐subscript𝜇𝐺top\Sigma_{B}=\frac{1}{K}\sum_{c=1}^{K}(\mu_{c}-\mu_{G})(\mu_{c}-\mu_{G})^{\top}.roman_Σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_μ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_G end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT . The NC2 metric on a feature matrix Z𝑍Zitalic_Z is defined as κ⁢(Z¯)𝜅¯𝑍\kappa(\bar{Z})italic_κ ( over¯ start_ARG italic_Z end_ARG ), i.e., the conditioning number of the class-mean matrix of Z.𝑍Z.italic_Z . The NC3 metric on a feature matrix Z𝑍Zitalic_Z and a weight matrix W𝑊Witalic_W is defined as 1N⁢∑c,icos⁡(zc⁢i,Wc:),1𝑁subscript𝑐𝑖subscript𝑧𝑐𝑖subscript𝑊:𝑐absent\frac{1}{N}\sum_{c,i}\cos(z_{ci},W_{c:}),divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_cos ( italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_c : end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , i.e., the average cosine similarity of features and weight vectors corresponding to the features’ class.

At this point, we state our result giving a set of sufficient conditions for NC1, NC2 and NC3.

Theorem 3.1.

If the network satisfies

  • •

    approximate interpolation, i.e., ‖ZL−Y‖F≤ϵ1subscriptnormsubscript𝑍𝐿𝑌𝐹subscriptitalic-ϵ1\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\epsilon_{1}∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • •

    approximate balancedness, i.e., ‖Wℓ+1⊤⁢Wℓ+1−Wℓ⁢Wℓ⊤‖o⁢p≤ϵ2subscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ1topsubscript𝑊ℓ1subscript𝑊ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓtop𝑜𝑝subscriptitalic-ϵ2\left\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\right\|_{op}\leq% \epsilon_{2}∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, for ℓ∈{L1+1,…,L−1}ℓsubscript𝐿11…𝐿1\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\ldots,L-1\}roman_ℓ ∈ { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , … , italic_L - 1 },

  • •

    bounded representations and weights, i.e., ‖ZL−2‖o⁢p,‖ZL−1‖o⁢p,‖Wℓ‖o⁢p≤rsubscriptnormsubscript𝑍𝐿2𝑜𝑝subscriptnormsubscript𝑍𝐿1𝑜𝑝subscriptnormsubscript𝑊ℓ𝑜𝑝𝑟\left\|Z_{L-2}\right\|_{op},\left\|Z_{L-1}\right\|_{op},\left\|W_{\ell}\right% \|_{op}\leq r∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_r, for ℓ∈{L1+1,…,L}ℓsubscript𝐿11…𝐿\ell\in\{L_{1}+1,\ldots,L\}roman_ℓ ∈ { italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 , … , italic_L },

then if ϵ1≤min(sK⁢(Y),(K−1)⁢N4⁢K)subscriptitalic-ϵ1minsubscript𝑠𝐾𝑌𝐾1𝑁4𝐾\epsilon_{1}\leq\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits\left(s_{K}(Y),\sqrt{\frac{(K-1)N}{4K% }}\right)italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ roman_min ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) , square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_K - 1 ) italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG ),

NC1⁢(ZL−1)≤r2N⁢(Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r))2(K−1K−2N⁢ϵ1)2,NC1subscript𝑍𝐿1superscript𝑟2𝑁superscriptΨsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟2superscript𝐾1𝐾2𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ12\text{NC1}(Z_{L-1})\leq\frac{r^{2}}{N}\frac{(\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)% )^{2}}{\left(\sqrt{\frac{K-1}{K}}-\frac{2}{\sqrt{N}}\epsilon_{1}\right)^{2}},NC1 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG divide start_ARG ( roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (2)

where Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)=r⁢(ϵ1sK⁢(Y)−ϵ1+nL−1⁢ϵ2)Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟𝑟subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑛𝐿1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)=r\left(\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon% _{1}}+\sqrt{n_{L-1}\epsilon_{2}}\right)roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) = italic_r ( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ). κ⁢(WL)≤c31L2⁢(1+ϵ)1L2+c31L2−1⁢ϵ,𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑐31subscript𝐿2superscript1italic-ϵ1subscript𝐿2superscriptsubscript𝑐31subscript𝐿21italic-ϵ\kappa(W_{L})\leq c_{3}^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}(1+\epsilon)^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}+{c_{3}% ^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}-1}}\epsilon,italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 1 + italic_ϵ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_c start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ , (3)

with ϵ=L222⁢r2⁢(L2−1)⁢ϵ2(sK⁢(Y)−ϵ1)2‖X‖o⁢p2⁢r2⁢L1−L222⁢r2⁢(L2−1)⁢ϵ2italic-ϵsuperscriptsubscript𝐿222superscript𝑟2subscript𝐿21subscriptitalic-ϵ2superscriptsubscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ12superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝2superscript𝑟2subscript𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝐿222superscript𝑟2subscript𝐿21subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon=\frac{\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{2(L_{2}-1)}\epsilon_{2}}{\frac{(s_{K}(Y)-% \epsilon_{1})^{2}}{\left\|X\right\|_{op}^{2}r^{2L_{1}}}-\frac{L_{2}^{2}}{2}r^{% 2(L_{2}-1)}\epsilon_{2}}italic_ϵ = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - divide start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Finally,

NC2⁢(ZL−1)NC2subscript𝑍𝐿1\displaystyle\text{NC2}(Z_{L-1})NC2 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤κ⁢(WL)+sK⁢(Y)−1⁢r⁢Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)1−sK⁢(Y)−1⁢r⁢Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)absent𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑠𝐾superscript𝑌1𝑟Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟1subscript𝑠𝐾superscript𝑌1𝑟Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟\displaystyle\leq\frac{\kappa(W_{L})+s_{K}(Y)^{-1}r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_% {2},r)}{1-s_{K}(Y)^{-1}r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)}≤ divide start_ARG italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG (4)
NC3⁢(ZL−1,WL)NC3subscript𝑍𝐿1subscript𝑊𝐿\displaystyle\text{NC3}(Z_{L-1},W_{L})NC3 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥(N−ϵ1)2+N⁢(κ⁢(WL))−2−(r⁢Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)+K⁢(κ⁢(WL)2−1))22⁢N⁢κ⁢(WL)⁢(1+ϵ1).absentsuperscript𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ12𝑁superscript𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿2superscript𝑟Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟𝐾𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿2122𝑁𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\displaystyle\geq\frac{(\sqrt{N}-\epsilon_{1})^{2}+N(\kappa(W_{L}))^{-2}-\left% (r\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)+\sqrt{K}(\kappa(W_{L})^{2}-1)\right)^{2}}{% 2N\kappa(W_{L})(1+\epsilon_{1})}.≥ divide start_ARG ( square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_N ( italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_r roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) + square-root start_ARG italic_K end_ARG ( italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_N italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ( 1 + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (5)

The restrictions ϵ1≤sK⁢(Y)subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌\epsilon_{1}\leq s_{K}(Y)italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) and ϵ1≤(K−1)⁢N4⁢Ksubscriptitalic-ϵ1𝐾1𝑁4𝐾\epsilon_{1}\leq\sqrt{\frac{(K-1)N}{4K}}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_K - 1 ) italic_N end_ARG start_ARG 4 italic_K end_ARG end_ARG are mild, and we are interested in the regime in which ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ1\epsilon_{1}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is small. In words, (2) shows that, when ϵ1,ϵ2≈0subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}\approx 0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ 0 (i.e., the network approximately interpolates the data in a balanced way), Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)≈0Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟0\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)\approx 0roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) ≈ 0 and the within-class variability (which captures NC1) vanishes. If in addition the depth of the linear part of the network grows, the RHS of (3) approaches 1, i.e., the last weight matrix WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to orthogonal. This implies that (i) ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is also close to orthogonal (which captures NC2), and (ii) the weights in the last layer align with ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (which captures NC3). In fact, when Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)≈0Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟0\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)\approx 0roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) ≈ 0 and κ⁢(WL)≈1𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿1\kappa(W_{L})\approx 1italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≈ 1, the RHS of both (4) and (5) is close to 1111. Below we give a proof sketch deferring the complete argument to Appendix B.

Proof sketch.

We start with NC1. If ZLsubscript𝑍𝐿Z_{L}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is already well-collapsed (which is guaranteed by the approximate interpolation) and WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is well-conditioned, then the only source of within-class variability in ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is within the null space of WL.subscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}.italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . However, if WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL−1subscript𝑊𝐿1W_{L-1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are balanced, the image of ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT must be approximately in a subspace of the row space of WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, hence, ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has little freedom within the kernel of WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. More formally, consider first the case of perfect balancedness (i.e., ϵ2=0subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{2}=0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0), and denote by WL+superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}^{+}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the pseudo-inverse of WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, Im⁢(ZL−1)⊂Im⁢(WL⊤)Imsubscript𝑍𝐿1Imsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿top\text{Im}(Z_{L-1})\subset\text{Im}(W_{L}^{\top})Im ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ⊂ Im ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and

∥WL+⁢WL⁢ZL−1−WL+⁢Y∥F=∥ZL−1−WL+⁢Y∥F≤ϵ1sK⁢(WL).subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑍𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌𝐹subscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑍𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌𝐹subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑠𝐾subscript𝑊𝐿\left\lVert W_{L}^{+}W_{L}Z_{L-1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\rVert_{F}=\left\lVert Z_{L-% 1}-W_{L}^{+}Y\right\rVert_{F}\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{s_{K}(W_{L})}.∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (6)

As sK⁢(WL)subscript𝑠𝐾subscript𝑊𝐿s_{K}(W_{L})italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) can be lower bounded by using the assumptions on approximate interpolation and boundedness of representations, the RHS of (6) is small and, therefore, ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to a matrix with zero within-class variability. Moving to the case ϵ2≠0subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{2}\neq 0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≠ 0, we need to show that WL+⁢WL⁢ZL−1superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑍𝐿1W_{L}^{+}W_{L}Z_{L-1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to ZL−1.subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}.italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . As WL+⁢WLsuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿subscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}^{+}W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT projects onto the row-space of WL,subscript𝑊𝐿W_{L},italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , only the part of ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in the kernel of WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT has to be considered. This part is controlled after writing ZL−1=WL−1⁢ZL−2subscript𝑍𝐿1subscript𝑊𝐿1subscript𝑍𝐿2Z_{L-1}=W_{L-1}Z_{L-2}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, using the boundedness of ZL−2subscript𝑍𝐿2Z_{L-2}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the approximate balancedness between WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL−1.subscript𝑊𝐿1W_{L-1}.italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . Finally, as ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to WL+⁢Y,superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌W_{L}^{+}Y,italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y , a direct computation yields the bound on NC1.

Next, to bound κ⁢(WL),𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿\kappa(W_{L}),italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , we notice that (WL⁢WL⊤)L2−(WL:L1+1⁢WL:L1+1⊤)superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿topsubscript𝐿2subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11superscriptsubscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11top(W_{L}W_{L}^{\top})^{L_{2}}-(W_{L:L_{1}+1}W_{L:L_{1}+1}^{\top})( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) has small operator norm, since the weights of linear layers are approximately balanced. This allows to upper bound κ⁢(WL)2⁢L2𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿2subscript𝐿2\kappa(W_{L})^{2L_{2}}italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT in terms of κ⁢(WL:L1+1)𝜅subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) (plus a small perturbation), which gives (3).

To lower bound the NC3 metric, we rescale ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to ZL−1′subscriptsuperscript𝑍′𝐿1Z^{\prime}_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝐿W^{\prime}_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, so that their columns and rows, respectively, have roughly equal size. Then, we reformulate the problem to proving that ⟨ZL−1′,WL′⁢Y⟩subscriptsuperscript𝑍′𝐿1subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝐿𝑌\left\langle Z^{\prime}_{L-1},W^{\prime}_{L}Y\right\rangle⟨ italic_Z start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_Y ⟩ is close to its theoretical maximum. We proceed to show this by arguing that, in this scaling and given that WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sufficiently well-conditioned, WL′subscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝐿W^{\prime}_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be replaced by (WL′)+superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑊′𝐿(W^{\prime}_{L})^{+}( italic_W start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to WL+⁢Ysuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌W_{L}^{+}Yitalic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y, we obtain (5). Finally, the bound on NC2 in (4) follows by combining (3) with the closeness between ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and WL+⁢Ysuperscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌W_{L}^{+}Yitalic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y already obtained in the proof of NC1.

4 Gradient Descent Leads to No Within-Class Variability (NC1)

In this section, we show that NC1 holds for a class of neural networks with one wide layer followed by a pyramidal topology, as considered in Nguyen & Mondelli (2020). To do so, we show that the balancedness and interpolation conditions of Theorem 3.1 holds. We expect that similar conditions – and, therefore, NC1 – also hold under minimal over-parameterization and for ReLU networks, adapting e.g. the approach of Bombari et al. (2022) and Zou & Gu (2019), respectively.

We consider a neural network as in (1), and we minimize the λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ-regularized square loss Cλ⁢(θ)=12⁢∥zL⁢(θ)−y∥22+λ2⁢∥θ∥22subscript𝐶𝜆𝜃12superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝑧𝐿𝜃𝑦22𝜆2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝜃22C_{\lambda}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\left\lVert z_{L}(\theta)-y\right\rVert_{2}^{2}% +\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\lVert\theta\right\rVert_{2}^{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) - italic_y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_θ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where zLsubscript𝑧𝐿z_{L}italic_z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and y𝑦yitalic_y are obtained by vectorizing ZLsubscript𝑍𝐿Z_{L}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Y𝑌Yitalic_Y, respectively, and θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ collects all the parameters of the network. To do so, we consider the gradient descent (GD) update θk+1=θk−η⁢∇Cλ⁢(θk)subscript𝜃𝑘1subscript𝜃𝑘𝜂∇subscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃𝑘\theta_{k+1}=\theta_{k}-\eta\nabla C_{\lambda}(\theta_{k})italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_η ∇ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), where η𝜂\etaitalic_η is the step size and θk=(Wℓk)ℓ=1Lsubscript𝜃𝑘superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ𝑘ℓ1𝐿\theta_{k}=(W_{\ell}^{k})_{\ell=1}^{L}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT contains all parameters at step k.𝑘k.italic_k . We also denote by Zℓksuperscriptsubscript𝑍ℓ𝑘Z_{\ell}^{k}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT the output of layer ℓℓ\ellroman_ℓ after k𝑘kitalic_k steps of GD. We make the following assumption on the pyramidal topology of the network, noting that this requirement is also common in prior work on the loss landscape (Nguyen & Hein, 2017, 2018).

Assumption 4.1.

(Pyramidal network topology) Let n1≥Nsubscript𝑛1𝑁n_{1}\geq Nitalic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_N and n2≥n3≥…≥nL.subscript𝑛2subscript𝑛3…subscript𝑛𝐿n_{2}\geq n_{3}\geq\ldots\geq n_{L}.italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ … ≥ italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

We make the following assumptions on the activation function σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ of the non-linear layers.

Assumption 4.2.

(Activation function) Fix γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1)italic_γ ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and β≥1𝛽1\beta\geq 1italic_β ≥ 1. Let σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ satisfy that: (i) σ′⁢(x)∈[γ,1]superscript𝜎′𝑥𝛾1\sigma^{\prime}(x)\in[\gamma,1]italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x ) ∈ [ italic_γ , 1 ], (ii) |σ⁢(x)|≤|x|𝜎𝑥𝑥|\sigma(x)|\leq|x|| italic_σ ( italic_x ) | ≤ | italic_x | for every x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R, and (iii) σ′superscript𝜎′\sigma^{\prime}italic_σ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is β𝛽\betaitalic_β-Lipschitz.

In principle, σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ can change at all layers, as long as it satisfies the above assumption. As an example, one can consider a family of parameterized ReLU functions, smoothened by a Gaussian kernel:

σ⁢(x)=−(1−γ)22⁢π⁢β+β1−γ⁢∫−∞∞max(γ⁢u,u)⁢e−π⁢β2⁢(x−u)2(1−γ)2⁢d⁢u.𝜎𝑥superscript1𝛾22𝜋𝛽𝛽1𝛾superscriptsubscriptmax𝛾𝑢𝑢superscript𝑒𝜋superscript𝛽2superscript𝑥𝑢2superscript1𝛾2𝑑𝑢\displaystyle\sigma(x)=-\frac{(1-\gamma)^{2}}{2\pi\beta}+\frac{\beta}{1-\gamma% }\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits(\gamma u,u)\,e^{-\frac{\pi% \beta^{2}(x-u)^{2}}{(1-\gamma)^{2}}}du.italic_σ ( italic_x ) = - divide start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_π italic_β end_ARG + divide start_ARG italic_β end_ARG start_ARG 1 - italic_γ end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max ( italic_γ italic_u , italic_u ) italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_π italic_β start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_x - italic_u ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ( 1 - italic_γ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_u . (7)

One can readily verify that the activation in (7) satisfies Assumption 4.2 and it uniformly approximates the ReLU function over ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R, see Lemma B.1 in Nguyen & Mondelli (2020). Next, let us introduce some notation111To avoid confusion, we note that this notation is different from the one used in (Nguyen & Mondelli, 2020). for the singular values of the weight matrices at initialization θ0=(Wℓ0)ℓ=1Lsubscript𝜃0superscriptsubscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ0ℓ1𝐿\theta_{0}=(W_{\ell}^{0})_{\ell=1}^{L}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT:

λℓ=σmin⁢(Wℓ0),λ¯ℓ=∥Wℓ0∥o⁢p+minℓ∈{3,…,L}λℓ,λi→j=∏ℓ=ijλℓ,λ¯i→j=∏ℓ=ijλ¯ℓ.formulae-sequencesubscript𝜆ℓsubscript𝜎minsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ0formulae-sequencesubscript¯𝜆ℓsubscriptdelimited-∥∥superscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ0𝑜𝑝subscriptminℓ3…𝐿subscript𝜆ℓformulae-sequencesubscript𝜆→𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptproductℓ𝑖𝑗subscript𝜆ℓsubscript¯𝜆→𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptproductℓ𝑖𝑗subscript¯𝜆ℓ\begin{split}&\lambda_{\ell}=\sigma_{\textrm{min}}\left(W_{\ell}^{0}\right),\,% \,\,\,\bar{\lambda}_{\ell}=\left\lVert W_{\ell}^{0}\right\rVert_{op}+\mathop{% \rm min}\nolimits_{\ell\in\{3,\ldots,L\}}\lambda_{\ell},\,\,\,\,\lambda_{i\to j% }=\prod_{\ell=i}^{j}\lambda_{\ell},\,\,\,\,\bar{\lambda}_{i\to j}=\prod_{\ell=% i}^{j}\bar{\lambda}_{\ell}.\\ \end{split}start_ROW start_CELL end_CELL start_CELL italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , over¯ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ∈ { 3 , … , italic_L } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i → italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , over¯ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i → italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over¯ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . end_CELL end_ROW (8)

We also define λF=σmin⁢(σ⁢(W10⁢X))subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜎min𝜎superscriptsubscript𝑊10𝑋\lambda_{F}=\sigma_{\textrm{min}}\left(\sigma(W_{1}^{0}X)\right)italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_σ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_σ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_X ) ) as the smallest singular value of the output of the first hidden layer at initialization. Finally, we make the following assumption on the initialization.

Assumption 4.3.

(Initial conditions)

λF⁢λ3→L⁢min(λF,minℓ∈{3,…,L}λℓ)≥8⁢γ⁢(2γ)L⁢C0⁢(θ0).subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆→3𝐿minsubscript𝜆𝐹subscriptminℓ3…𝐿subscript𝜆ℓ8𝛾superscript2𝛾𝐿subscript𝐶0subscript𝜃0\displaystyle\lambda_{F}\lambda_{3\to L}\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits(\lambda_{F},% \mathop{\rm min}\nolimits_{\ell\in\{3,\ldots,L\}}\lambda_{\ell})\geq 8\gamma% \sqrt{\left(\frac{2}{\gamma}\right)^{L}C_{0}(\theta_{0})}.italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 → italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min ( italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ∈ { 3 , … , italic_L } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ 8 italic_γ square-root start_ARG ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG . (9)

We note that (9) can be satisfied by choosing a sufficiently small initialization for the second layer and a sufficiently large one for the remaining layers. In fact, the LHS of (9) depends on all the layer weights except the second, so this quantity can be made arbitrarily large. Next, by taking a sufficiently small second layer, the term 2⁢C0⁢(θ)=‖ZL−Y‖F2subscript𝐶0𝜃subscriptnormsubscript𝑍𝐿𝑌𝐹\sqrt{2C_{0}(\theta)}=\|Z_{L}-Y\|_{F}square-root start_ARG 2 italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) end_ARG = ∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be upper bounded by 2⁢‖Y‖F2subscriptnorm𝑌𝐹2\|Y\|_{F}2 ∥ italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. As a consequence, the RHS of (9) is at most 8⁢2⁢‖Y‖F⁢γ⁢(2γ)L/282subscriptnorm𝑌𝐹𝛾superscript2𝛾𝐿28\sqrt{2}\|Y\|_{F}\gamma\big{(}\frac{2}{\gamma}\big{)}^{L/2}8 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_γ ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_γ end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As the LHS of (9) can be arbitrarily large, the inequality holds for a suitable initialization.

Theorem 4.4.

Let the network satisfy Assumption 4.1, σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ satisfy Assumption 4.2 and the initial conditions satisfy Assumption 4.3. Fix 0<ϵ1≤12⁢(K−1)⁢NK0subscriptitalic-ϵ112𝐾1𝑁𝐾0<\epsilon_{1}\leq\frac{1}{2}\sqrt{\frac{(K-1)N}{K}}0 < italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG ( italic_K - 1 ) italic_N end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG, ϵ2>0subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{2}>0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT > 0, let b≥1𝑏1b\geq 1italic_b ≥ 1 be s.t. ‖X:i‖2≤bsubscriptnormsubscript𝑋:absent𝑖2𝑏\|X_{:i}\|_{2}\leq b∥ italic_X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_b for all i𝑖iitalic_i, and run k𝑘kitalic_k steps of λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ-regularized GD with step size η𝜂\etaitalic_η, where

λ≤min(2⁢(γ2)L−2⁢λF⁢λ3→L,2⁢C0⁢(θ0)∥θ0∥22,ϵ1218⁢(∥θ0∥2+λF/2)2),η≤min(12⁢β1,15⁢N⁢β⁢b3⁢max(1,(2⁢ϵ12λ)3⁢L/2)⁢L5/2,12⁢λ,(λ2⁢ϵ12)L1+L⁢ϵ24⁢‖X‖o⁢p2),k≥⌈log⁡λ⁢mλCλ⁢(θ0)−λ⁢mλlog⁡(1−η⁢α8)⌉+⌈log⁡λ⁢ϵ24⁢ϵ12log⁡(1−η⁢λ)⌉,formulae-sequence𝜆min2superscript𝛾2𝐿2subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆→3𝐿2subscript𝐶0subscript𝜃0superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜃022superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ1218superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥subscript𝜃02subscript𝜆𝐹22formulae-sequence𝜂min12subscript𝛽115𝑁𝛽superscript𝑏3max1superscript2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12𝜆3𝐿2superscript𝐿5212𝜆superscript𝜆2superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12subscript𝐿1𝐿subscriptitalic-ϵ24superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝2𝑘𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆subscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃0𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆1𝜂𝛼8𝜆subscriptitalic-ϵ24superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ121𝜂𝜆\begin{split}\lambda&\leq\mathop{\rm + italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT / 2 ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_η end_CELL start_CELL ≤ roman_min ( end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 4 ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_k end_CELL start_CELL ≥ ⌈ divide start_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_λ with β1=5⁢N⁢β⁢b3⁢(∏ℓ=1Lmax(1,λ¯ℓ))3⁢L5/2subscript𝛽15𝑁𝛽superscript𝑏3superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptproductℓ1𝐿max1subscript¯𝜆ℓ3superscript𝐿52\beta_{1}=5N\beta b^{3}\left(\prod_{\ell=1}^{L}\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits(1,% \bar{\lambda}_{\ell})\right)^{3}L^{5/2}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 5 italic_N italic_β italic_b start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∏ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_max ( 1 , over¯ start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 5 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, mλ=(1+4⁢λ/α)2⁢(‖θ0‖2+r0)2subscript𝑚𝜆superscript14𝜆𝛼2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃02subscript𝑟02m_{\lambda}=(1+\sqrt{4\lambda/\alpha})^{2}\left(\left\|\theta_{0}\right\|_{2}+% r_{0}\right)^{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 + square-root start_ARG 4 italic_λ / italic_α end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, r0=12⁢min(λF,minℓ∈{3,…,L}λℓ)subscript𝑟012minsubscript𝜆𝐹subscriptminℓ3…𝐿subscript𝜆ℓr_{0}=\frac{1}{2}\mathop{\rm min}\nolimits(\lambda_{F},\mathop{\rm min}% \nolimits_{\ell\in\{3,\ldots,L\}}\lambda_{\ell})italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_min ( italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ ∈ { 3 , … , italic_L } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), and α=2−(L−3)⁢γL−2⁢λF⁢λ3→L𝛼superscript2𝐿3superscript𝛾𝐿2subscript𝜆𝐹subscript𝜆→3𝐿\alpha=2^{-(L-3)}\gamma^{L-2}\lambda_{F}\lambda_{3\to L}italic_α = 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( italic_L - 3 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_γ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 3 → italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then, we have that

NC1⁢(ZL−1k)≤r2N⁢Ψ⁢(ϵ1⁢2,ϵ2,r)(K−1K−2⁢2N⁢ϵ1)2,NC1superscriptsubscript𝑍𝐿1𝑘superscript𝑟2𝑁Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ12subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟superscript𝐾1𝐾22𝑁subscriptitalic-ϵ12\text{NC1}(Z_{L-1}^{k})\leq\frac{r^{2}}{N}\frac{\Psi(\epsilon_{1}\sqrt{2},% \epsilon_{2},r)}{\left(\sqrt{\frac{K-1}{K}}-\frac{2\sqrt{2}}{\sqrt{N}}\epsilon% _{1}\right)^{2}},NC1 ( italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_N end_ARG divide start_ARG roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) end_ARG start_ARG ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_K - 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_K end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_N end_ARG end_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , (11)

with Ψ⁢(ϵ1,ϵ2,r)=r⁢(ϵ1sK⁢(Y)−ϵ1+nL−1⁢ϵ2)Ψsubscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝑟𝑟subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscript𝑛𝐿1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\Psi(\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2},r)=r\left(\frac{\epsilon_{1}}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon% _{1}}+\sqrt{n_{L-1}\epsilon_{2}}\right)roman_Ψ ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r ) = italic_r ( divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) and

r=max(ϵ1⁢2λ,(ϵ1⁢2λ)L−2⁢‖X‖o⁢p,(ϵ1⁢2λ)L−1⁢‖X‖o⁢p).𝑟maxsubscriptitalic-ϵ12𝜆superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12𝜆𝐿2subscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12𝜆𝐿1subscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝r=\mathop{\rm max}\nolimits\left(\epsilon_{1}\sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}},\left(% \epsilon_{1}\sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}}\right)^{L-2}\|X\|_{op},\left(\epsilon_{1}% \sqrt{\frac{2}{\lambda}}\right)^{L-1}\|X\|_{op}\right).italic_r = roman_max ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG end_ARG , ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ( italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (12)

In words, if regularization and learning rate are small enough and we run GD for sufficiently long (as in (10)), then the within-class variability vanishes (as in (11)). To interpret the result, note that the NC1 metric tends to 00 (i.e., the collapse is perfect) as ϵ1,ϵ2→0→subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ20\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}\to 0italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → 0. Since the terms β1,mλ,r0,αsubscript𝛽1subscript𝑚𝜆subscript𝑟0𝛼\beta_{1},m_{\lambda},r_{0},\alphaitalic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_α do not depend on ϵ1,ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{1},\epsilon_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (but just on the network architecture and initialization), taking λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ of order ϵ12superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12\epsilon_{1}^{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and η𝜂\etaitalic_η of order ϵ2subscriptitalic-ϵ2\epsilon_{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies the first two requirements in (10), also giving that r𝑟ritalic_r in (12) is of constant order. Finally, as log⁡(1−x)≈−x1𝑥𝑥\log(1-x)\approx-xroman_log ( 1 - italic_x ) ≈ - italic_x for small x𝑥xitalic_x, the quantity η⁢k𝜂𝑘\eta kitalic_η italic_k – which quantifies the time of the dynamics, since it is the product of learning rate and number of GD steps – is of order log⁡(1/λ)+log⁡(1/ϵ2)/λ1𝜆1subscriptitalic-ϵ2𝜆\log(1/\lambda)+\log(1/\epsilon_{2})/\lambdaroman_log ( 1 / italic_λ ) + roman_log ( 1 / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_λ. Below we provide a proof sketch deferring the full argument to Appendix B.

Proof sketch.

We show that the network trained via λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ-regularized GD fulfills the three sufficient conditions for NC1 given by Theorem 3.1, i.e., approximate interpolation, approximate balancedness and bounded representations/weights. To do so, we distinguish two phases in the training dynamics.

The first phase lasts for logarithmic time in 1/λ1𝜆1/\lambda1 / italic_λ (or, equivalently, 1/ϵ11subscriptitalic-ϵ11/\epsilon_{1}1 / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT) and, here, the loss decreases exponentially fast to a value of at most 2⁢λ⁢mλ≤ϵ122𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ122\lambda m_{\lambda}\leq\epsilon_{1}^{2}2 italic_λ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. As the learning rate is small enough, the loss cannot increase during the GD dynamics, which already gives approximate interpolation. To show the exponential convergence, we proceed in two steps. First, Lemma 4.1 in (Nguyen & Mondelli, 2020) gives that the unregularized loss C0⁢(θ)subscript𝐶0𝜃C_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) satisfies the Polyak-Lojasiewicz (PL) inequality

‖∇C0⁢(θ)‖22≥α2⁢C0⁢(θ),superscriptsubscriptnorm∇subscript𝐶0𝜃22𝛼2subscript𝐶0𝜃\left\|\nabla C_{0}(\theta)\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\alpha}{2}C_{0}(\theta),∥ ∇ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) , (13)

for all θ𝜃\thetaitalic_θ in a ball centered at initialization θ0subscript𝜃0\theta_{0}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and with sufficiently large radius (captured by r0subscript𝑟0r_{0}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Next, we show that, if C0⁢(θ)subscript𝐶0𝜃C_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) satisfies the α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-PL inequality in (13), then the regularized loss Cλ⁢(θ)=C0⁢(θ)+λ2⁢‖θ‖22subscript𝐶𝜆𝜃subscript𝐶0𝜃𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃22C_{\lambda}(\theta)=C_{0}(\theta)+\frac{\lambda}{2}\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) + divide start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_θ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT satisfies a shifted α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-PL inequality, which implies exponential convergence. This second step is formalized by the proposition below proved in Appendix B.

Proposition 4.5.

Let C0⁢(θ)subscript𝐶0𝜃C_{0}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) satisfy the α𝛼\alphaitalic_α-PL inequality (13) in the ball B⁢(θ0,r0)𝐵subscript𝜃0subscript𝑟0B(\theta_{0},r_{0})italic_B ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then, in the same ball, Cλ⁢(θ)subscript𝐶𝜆𝜃C_{\lambda}(\theta)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) satisfies the inequality

∥∇Cλ(θ))∥22≥α4(Cλ(θ)−λmλ),\left\|\nabla C_{\lambda}(\theta))\right\|_{2}^{2}\geq\frac{\alpha}{4}\left(C_% {\lambda}(\theta)-\lambda m_{\lambda}\right),∥ ∇ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) ) ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≥ divide start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ( italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) - italic_λ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , (14)

where mλ=(1+4⁢λ/α)2⁢(‖θ0‖2+r0)2subscript𝑚𝜆superscript14𝜆𝛼2superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃02subscript𝑟02m_{\lambda}=(1+\sqrt{4\lambda/\alpha})^{2}\left(\left\|\theta_{0}\right\|_{2}+% r_{0}\right)^{2}italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( 1 + square-root start_ARG 4 italic_λ / italic_α end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Furthermore, assume that r0≥8⁢Cλ⁢(θ0)/αsubscript𝑟08subscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃0𝛼r_{0}\geq 8\sqrt{C_{\lambda}(\theta_{0})/\alpha}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 8 square-root start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) / italic_α end_ARG and ∇C0⁢(θ)∇subscript𝐶0𝜃\nabla C_{0}(\theta)∇ italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) is β1subscript𝛽1\beta_{1}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-Lipschitz in B⁢(θ0,r0)𝐵subscript𝜃0subscript𝑟0B(\theta_{0},r_{0})italic_B ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Then, for any η<1/(2⁢β1)𝜂12subscript𝛽1\eta<1/(2\beta_{1})italic_η < 1 / ( 2 italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), there exists

k1≤⌈log⁡λ⁢mλCλ⁢(θ0)−λ⁢mλlog⁡(1−η⁢α8)⌉subscript𝑘1𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆subscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃0𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆1𝜂𝛼8k_{1}\leq\left\lceil\frac{\log\frac{\lambda m_{\lambda}}{C_{\lambda}(\theta_{0% })-\lambda m_{\lambda}}}{\log(1-\eta\frac{\alpha}{8})}\right\rceilitalic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ ⌈ divide start_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_λ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - italic_λ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG roman_log ( 1 - italic_η divide start_ARG italic_α end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) end_ARG ⌉ (15)

such that the k1subscript𝑘1k_{1}italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT-th iterate of GD satisfies

Cλ⁢(θk1)≤2⁢λ⁢mλ,‖θk1−θ0‖2≤8⁢Cλ⁢(θ0)α≤r0.formulae-sequencesubscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃subscript𝑘12𝜆subscript𝑚𝜆subscriptnormsubscript𝜃subscript𝑘1subscript𝜃028subscript𝐶𝜆subscript𝜃0𝛼subscript𝑟0C_{\lambda}(\theta_{k_{1}})\leq 2\lambda m_{\lambda},\qquad\qquad\left\|\theta% _{k_{1}}-\theta_{0}\right\|_{2}\leq 8\sqrt{\frac{C_{\lambda}(\theta_{0})}{% \alpha}}\leq r_{0}.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ 2 italic_λ italic_m start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 8 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG end_ARG ≤ italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (16)

The second phase lasts for linear time in 1/λ1𝜆1/\lambda1 / italic_λ (or, equivalently in 1/ϵ121superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ121/\epsilon_{1}^{2}1 / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT) and logarithmic time in 1/ϵ21subscriptitalic-ϵ21/\epsilon_{2}1 / italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and, here, the weight matrices in the linear part of the network become balanced. More precisely, we show that, if Wℓsubscript𝑊ℓW_{\ell}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is a weight matrix of the linear part, ‖Wℓ+1⊤⁢Wℓ+1−Wℓ⁢Wℓ⊤‖o⁢psubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓ1topsubscript𝑊ℓ1subscript𝑊ℓsuperscriptsubscript𝑊ℓtop𝑜𝑝\|W_{\ell+1}^{\top}W_{\ell+1}-W_{\ell}W_{\ell}^{\top}\|_{op}∥ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT decreases exponentially and the exponent scales with 1/λ1𝜆1/\lambda1 / italic_λ, which gives approximate balancedness. Finally, as the regularization term in the loss is at most ϵ12superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12\epsilon_{1}^{2}italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, the operator norm of representations and weight matrices is bounded by r𝑟ritalic_r as in (12), and the proof is completed by an application of Theorem 3.1.

5 Orthogonality of Class Means (NC2) and Alignment with Last Weight Matrix (NC3)

To guarantee the orthogonality of class means and their alignment with the last weight matrix, the crux is to show that the condition number κ⁢(WL)𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿\kappa(W_{L})italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) of the last weight matrix WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is close to one. In fact, as ZL−1≈WL+⁢Ysubscript𝑍𝐿1superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿𝑌Z_{L-1}\approx W_{L}^{+}Yitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≈ italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_Y, this implies that the last hidden representation ZL−1subscript𝑍𝐿1Z_{L-1}italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is approximately a rotation and rescaling of Y𝑌Yitalic_Y, which gives NC2, and a bound on NC3 of the form in (5) also follows.

The fact that κ⁢(WL)≈1𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿1\kappa(W_{L})\approx 1italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≈ 1 is a consequence of the presence of many balanced linear layers. Indeed, balancedness implies WL⁢WL⊤=(WL:L1+1⁢WL:L1+1⊤)1L2subscript𝑊𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑊𝐿topsuperscriptsubscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11superscriptsubscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11top1subscript𝐿2W_{L}W_{L}^{\top}=(W_{L:L_{1}+1}W_{L:L_{1}+1}^{\top})^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, which gives that κ⁢(WL)=κ⁢(WL:L1+1)1L2𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿𝜅superscriptsubscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿111subscript𝐿2\kappa(W_{L})=\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})^{\frac{1}{L_{2}}}italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Thus, if the conditioning of the product of the linear layers WL:L1+1subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be bounded independently of L2subscript𝐿2L_{2}italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, one can guarantee that the conditioning of WLsubscript𝑊𝐿W_{L}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT approaches 1111 as L2→∞→subscript𝐿2L_{2}\to\inftyitalic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT → ∞. As this is difficult to obtain in full generality (in particular the assumptions of Theorem 3.1 may not be sufficient), we show that the conditioning can be controlled (i) at any global minimizer, and (ii) when the parameters are ‘stable’ under large learning rates.

5.1 Global Minimizers

We first show that any set of parameters that approximately interpolate with small norm has bounded condition number. We will then show that with the right choice of widths and ridge, all global minimizers satisfy these two assumptions.

Proposition 5.1.

Let σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ satisfy Assumption 4.2. Then, for any network that satisfies

  • •

    approximate interpolation, i.e., ‖ZL−Y‖F≤ϵ1subscriptnormsubscript𝑍𝐿𝑌𝐹subscriptitalic-ϵ1\left\|Z_{L}-Y\right\|_{F}\leq\epsilon_{1}∥ italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - italic_Y ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT,

  • •

    bounded parameters, i.e., ‖θ‖22≤L⁢K+csuperscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃22𝐿𝐾𝑐\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}\leq LK+c∥ italic_θ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≤ italic_L italic_K + italic_c,

the linear part WL:L1+1subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11W_{L:L_{1}+1}italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies

κ⁢(WL:L1+1)≤exp⁡(12⁢(c+L1⁢K⁢log⁡K−2⁢K⁢log⁡sK⁢(Y)−ϵ1‖X‖o⁢p)).𝜅subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿1112𝑐subscript𝐿1𝐾𝐾2𝐾subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ1subscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})\leq\exp\left(\frac{1}{2}\left(c+L_{1}K\log K-2K\log\frac% {s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}\right)\right).italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ roman_exp ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_c + italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K roman_log italic_K - 2 italic_K roman_log divide start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) ) . (17)
Theorem 5.2.

Let σ𝜎\sigmaitalic_σ satisfy Assumption 4.2. Assume there exist parameters of the nonlinear part θn⁢o⁢n⁢l⁢i⁢n=(Wℓ)ℓ=1L1subscript𝜃𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑙𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝑊ℓℓ1subscript𝐿1\theta_{nonlin}=(W_{\ell})_{\ell=1}^{L_{1}}italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_ℓ = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT such that ZL1=Ysubscript𝑍subscript𝐿1𝑌Z_{L_{1}}=Yitalic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_Y and ‖θn⁢o⁢n⁢l⁢i⁢n‖22=csuperscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝜃𝑛𝑜𝑛𝑙𝑖𝑛22𝑐\|\theta_{nonlin}\|_{2}^{2}=c∥ italic_θ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n italic_o italic_n italic_l italic_i italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_c. Then, at any global minimizer of the regularized loss ℒλ⁢(θ)=12⁢‖Y−ZL‖F2+λ2⁢‖θ‖22subscriptℒ𝜆𝜃12superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑌subscript𝑍𝐿𝐹2𝜆2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝜃22\mathcal{L}_{\lambda}(\theta)=\frac{1}{2}\left\|Y-Z_{L}\right\|_{F}^{2}+\frac{% \lambda}{2}\left\|\theta\right\|_{2}^{2}caligraphic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_θ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_Y - italic_Z start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ italic_θ ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with λ≤ϵ12K⁢L+c𝜆superscriptsubscriptitalic-ϵ12𝐾𝐿𝑐\lambda\leq\frac{\epsilon_{1}^{2}}{KL+c}italic_λ ≤ divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_K italic_L + italic_c end_ARG, we have

κ⁢(WL:L1+1)≤(‖X‖o⁢psK⁢(Y)−ϵ1)K⁢exp⁡(12⁢(c−L1⁢K+L1⁢K⁢log⁡K)),κ⁢(WL)≤(‖X‖o⁢psK⁢(Y)−ϵ1)KL1⁢exp⁡(12⁢L1⁢(c−L1⁢K+L1⁢K⁢log⁡K)).formulae-sequence𝜅subscript𝑊:𝐿subscript𝐿11superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝐾12𝑐subscript𝐿1𝐾subscript𝐿1𝐾𝐾𝜅subscript𝑊𝐿superscriptsubscriptnorm𝑋𝑜𝑝subscript𝑠𝐾𝑌subscriptitalic-ϵ1𝐾subscript𝐿112subscript𝐿1𝑐subscript𝐿1𝐾subscript𝐿1𝐾𝐾\begin{split}\kappa(W_{L:L_{1}+1})&\leq\left(\frac{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}{s_{K% }(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}\right)^{K}\exp\left(\frac{1}{2}\left(c-L_{1}K+L_{1}K\log K% \right)\right),\\ \kappa(W_{L})&\leq\left(\frac{\left\|X\right\|_{op}}{s_{K}(Y)-\epsilon_{1}}% \right)^{\frac{K}{L_{1}}}\exp\left(\frac{1}{2L_{1}}\left(c-L_{1}K+L_{1}K\log K% \right)\right).\end{split}start_ROW start_CELL italic_κ ( italic_W start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_L : italic_L start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL start_CELL ≤ ( divide start_ARG ∥ italic_X ∥ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_o italic_p end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_Y ) -
